detaileddescription.para: Initialize Ring Buffer to empty state ready to have elements written to it.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.
The size of a single data element in bytes.
The number of elements in the buffer (must be a power of 2).
A pointer to a previously allocated area where the data will be maintained. It must be elementCount*elementSizeBytes long.

simplesect.para: -1 if elementCount is not a power of 2, otherwise 0.

detaileddescription.para: Reset buffer to empty. Should only be called when buffer is NOT being read or written.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Retrieve the number of elements available in the ring buffer for writing.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.

simplesect.para: The number of elements available for writing.

detaileddescription.para: Retrieve the number of elements available in the ring buffer for reading.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.

simplesect.para: The number of elements available for reading.

detaileddescription.para: Write data to the ring buffer.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.
The address of new data to write to the buffer.
The number of elements to be written.

detaileddescription.para: Read data from the ring buffer.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.
The address where the data should be stored.
The number of elements to be read.

memberdef.argsstring: (PaUtilRingBuffer *rbuf, ring_buffer_size_t elementCount, void **dataPtr1, ring_buffer_size_t *sizePtr1, void **dataPtr2, ring_buffer_size_t *sizePtr2)
memberdef.name: PaUtil_GetRingBufferWriteRegions

detaileddescription.para: Get address of region(s) to which we can write data.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.
The number of elements desired.
The address where the first (or only) region pointer will be stored.
The address where the first (or only) region length will be stored.
The address where the second region pointer will be stored if the first region is too small to satisfy elementCount.
The address where the second region length will be stored if the first region is too small to satisfy elementCount.

simplesect.para: The room available to be written or elementCount, whichever is smaller.

detaileddescription.para: Advance the write index to the next location to be written.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.
The number of elements to advance.

memberdef.argsstring: (PaUtilRingBuffer *rbuf, ring_buffer_size_t elementCount, void **dataPtr1, ring_buffer_size_t *sizePtr1, void **dataPtr2, ring_buffer_size_t *sizePtr2)
memberdef.name: PaUtil_GetRingBufferReadRegions

detaileddescription.para: Get address of region(s) from which we can read data.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.
The number of elements desired.
The address where the first (or only) region pointer will be stored.
The address where the first (or only) region length will be stored.
The address where the second region pointer will be stored if the first region is too small to satisfy elementCount.
The address where the second region length will be stored if the first region is too small to satisfy elementCount.

simplesect.para: The number of elements available for reading.

detaileddescription.para: Advance the read index to the next location to be read.

parameterdescription.para: The ring buffer.
The number of elements to advance.

detaileddescription.para: PaUtilRingBuffer is a ring buffer used to transport samples between different execution contexts (threads, OS callbacks, interrupt handlers) without requiring the use of any locks. This only works when there is a single reader and a single writer (ie. one thread or callback writes to the ring buffer, another thread or callback reads from it).
The PaUtilRingBuffer structure manages a ring buffer containing N elements, where N must be a power of two. An element may be any size (specified in bytes).
The memory area used to store the buffer elements must be allocated by the client prior to calling PaUtil_InitializeRingBuffer() and must outlive the use of the ring buffer.

simplesect.para: The ring buffer functions are not normally exposed in the PortAudio libraries. If you want to call them then you will need to add pa_ringbuffer.c to your application source code.
